column2: They shall never do it, never! cried the young man.

column2: And then a sharp rapping on the desk terminated the brief conversation and restored quietness to the little courtroom.

column2: THE WEIGHT OF EVIDENCE

column2: The next witness called was Mrs. Morse, who told briefly how she had been placed in charge of the upper part of the Langmore mansion shortly after the tragedy, and how she had been watching Margaret.
column3: The next witness called was mrs Morse, who told briefly how she had been placed in charge of the upper part of the Langmore mansion shortly after the tragedy, and how she had been watching Margaret.

column2: She said the girl had had only a few visitors, mentioning Raymond Case and a stranger from New York.
column3: She said the girl had had only a few visitors, mentioning Raymond Case and a stranger from New York.

column2: Who was the stranger? asked Coroner Busby.
column3: Who was the stranger? asked Coroner Busby.

column2: A Mr. Adams.	A mr Adams.

column2: He's either a lawyer or a detective."
column3: He's either a lawyer or a detective."

column2: Oh!

column2: Wasn't that all right?
column3: Wasn't that all right?

column3: What did she say about mrs Langmore?

column3: She does not seem to care much about her stepmother.

column3: Have you discovered anything unusual, mrs Morse, that had to do with this tragedy?

column2: I went on hunting around the house and I found the other half of the handkerchief in a dark corner of the upper hallway, not far from where Mrs. Langmore's body was found."

column2: Shall I read it?" And as the coroner nodded, the woman read as follows:
column3: Shall I read it?" And as the coroner nodded, the woman read as follows:

column2: You must either obey your mother that now is, and me, or leave this house.

column3: I have had enough of your willfulness and I shall not put up with it any longer."

column2: We find that Mr. and Mrs. Barry Langmore came to their deaths either by being smothered, chloroformed, poisoned, or in some similar fashion, the direct means not yet being brought to light, and we find that the evidence points to Margaret Langmore as the one who committed the murders.
